member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.BillboardCesiumWriter.ImageWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the image property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The image property defines the URI of the image displayed on the billboard. For broadest client compatibility, the URI should be accessible via Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS). The URI may also be a data URI.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.BillboardCesiumWriter.ScaleWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the scale property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The scale property defines the scale of the billboard. The scale is multiplied with the pixel size of the billboard's image. For example, if the scale is 2.0, the billboard will be rendered with twice the number of pixels, in each direction, of the image. If not specified, the default value is 1.0.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.BillboardCesiumWriter.PixelOffsetWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the pixelOffset property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The pixelOffset property defines the offset, in viewport pixels, of the billboard origin from the position. A pixel offset is the number of pixels up and to the right to place the billboard, relative to the position.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.BillboardCesiumWriter.EyeOffsetWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the eyeOffset property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The eyeOffset property defines the eye offset of the billboard, which is the offset in eye coordinates at which to place the billboard relative to the position property. Eye coordinates are a left-handed coordinate system where the X-axis points toward the viewer's right, the Y-axis points up, and the Z-axis points into the screen.

The alignedAxis property specifies the aligned axis is the unit vector, in world coordinates, that the billboard up vector points towards. The default is the zero vector, which means the billboard is aligned to the screen up vector.
member.param: The identifier of the object which contains the referenced property.
The property on the referenced object.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.BillboardCesiumWriter.SizeInMetersWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the sizeInMeters property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The sizeInMeters property defines whether this billboard's size (width and height) should be measured in meters, otherwise size is measured in pixels. If not specified, the default value is .

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.ClockCesiumWriter.WriteMultiplier(System.Double)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a multiplier, which is the multiplier. When step is set to TICK_DEPENDENT, this is the number of seconds to advance each tick. When step is set to SYSTEM_CLOCK_DEPENDENT, this is multiplied by the elapsed system time between ticks. This value is ignored in SYSTEM_CLOCK mode. The default value is 1.0.
member.param: The value.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.ClockCesiumWriter.WriteRange(CesiumLanguageWriter.ClockRange)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a range, which is the behavior when the current time reaches its start or end times. The default value is LOOP_STOP.
member.param: The clock range.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.ClockCesiumWriter.WriteStep(CesiumLanguageWriter.ClockStep)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a step, which is how the current time advances each tick. The default value is SYSTEM_CLOCK_MULTIPLIER.
member.param: The clock step.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.CorridorCesiumWriter

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.DirectionCesiumWriter.WriteSpherical(CesiumLanguageWriter.Spherical)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a spherical, which is the direction specified as a spherical value [Clock, Cone, Magnitude], with angles in radians and magnitude in meters. The clock angle is measured in the XY plane from the positive X axis toward the positive Y axis. The cone angle is the angle from the positive Z axis toward the negative Z axis.
member.param: The value.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.EyeOffsetCesiumWriter
member.summary: Writes a EyeOffset to a . A EyeOffset is an offset in eye coordinates which can optionally vary over time. Eye coordinates are a left-handed coordinate system where the X-axis points toward the viewer's right, the Y-axis poitns up, and the Z-axis points into the screen.

member.summary: The name of the cartesian property.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.EyeOffsetCesiumWriter.WriteCartesian(CesiumLanguageWriter.Cartesian)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a cartesian, which is the eye offset specified as a three-dimensional Cartesian value [X, Y, Z], in eye coordinates in meters. If the array has three elements, the eye offset is constant. If it has four or more elements, they are time-tagged samples arranged as [Time, X, Y, Z, Time, X, Y, Z, ...], where Time is an ISO 8601 date and time string or seconds since epoch.
member.param: The value.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.EyeOffsetCesiumWriter.WriteCartesian(System.Collections.Generic.IList{CesiumLanguageWriter.JulianDate},System.Collections.Generic.IList{CesiumLanguageWriter.Cartesian})

member.param: The dates at which the value is specified.
The values corresponding to each date.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.LabelCesiumWriter.ScaleWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the scale property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The scale property defines the scale of the label. The scale is multiplied with the pixel size of the label's text. For example, if the scale is 2.0, the label will be rendered with twice the number of pixels, in each direction, of the text. If not specified, the default value is 1.0.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.LabelCesiumWriter.EyeOffsetWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the eyeOffset property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The eyeOffset property defines the eye offset of the label, which is the offset in eye coordinates at which to place the label relative to the position property. Eye coordinates are a left-handed coordinate system where the X-axis points toward the viewer's right, the Y-axis points up, and the Z-axis points into the screen.

The horizontalOrigin property defines the horizontal origin of the label. It controls whether the label is left-, center-, or right-aligned with the position. If not specified, the default value is CENTER.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.LabelCesiumWriter.OpenHorizontalOriginProperty
member.summary: Opens and returns the writer for the horizontalOrigin property. The horizontalOrigin property defines the horizontal origin of the label. It controls whether the label is left-, center-, or right-aligned with the position. If not specified, the default value is CENTER.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.LabelCesiumWriter.WriteHorizontalOriginProperty(CesiumLanguageWriter.CesiumHorizontalOrigin)
member.summary: Writes a value for the horizontalOrigin property as a horizontalOrigin value. The horizontalOrigin property specifies the horizontal origin of the label. It controls whether the label is left-, center-, or right-aligned with the position. If not specified, the default value is CENTER.
member.param: The horizontal origin.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.ModelCesiumWriter.ColorBlendAmountWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the colorBlendAmount property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The colorBlendAmount property defines the color strength when colorBlendMode is MIX. A value of 0.0 results in the model's rendered color while a value of 1.0 results in a solid color, with any value in-between resulting in a mix of the two. If not specified, the default value is 0.5.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.NearFarScalarCesiumWriter
member.summary: Writes a NearFarScalar to a . A NearFarScalar is a numeric value which will be linearly interpolated between two values based on an object's distance from the camera, in eye coordinates. The computed value will interpolate between the near value and the far value while the camera distance falls between the near distance and the far distance, and will be clamped to the near or far value while the distance is less than the near distance or greater than the far distance, respectively.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.WriteId(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a id, which is the ID of the object described by this packet. IDs do not need to be GUIDs, but they do need to uniquely identify a single object within a CZML source and any other CZML sources loaded into the same scope. If this property is not specified, the client will automatically generate a unique one. However, this prevents later packets from referring to this object in order to add more data to it.
member.param: The value.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.WriteDelete(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a delete, which is whether the client should delete all existing data for this object, identified by ID. If true, all other properties in this packet will be ignored.
member.param: The value.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.WriteName(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a name, which is the name of the object. It does not have to be unique and is intended for user consumption.
member.param: The value.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.WriteParent(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a parent, which is the ID of the parent object, if any.
member.param: The value.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.WriteAvailability(CesiumLanguageWriter.TimeInterval)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a availability, which is the set of time intervals over which data for an object is available. The property can be a single string specifying a single interval, or an array of strings representing intervals. A later Cesium packet can update this availability if it changes or is found to be incorrect. For example, an SGP4 propagator may initially report availability for all time, but then later the propagator throws an exception and the availability can be adjusted to end at that time. If this optional property is not present, the object is assumed to be available for all time. Availability is scoped to a particular CZML stream, so two different streams can list different availability for a single object. Within a single stream, the last availability stated for an object is the one in effect and any availabilities in previous packets are ignored. If an object is not available at a time, the client will not draw that object. If not specified, the default value is 0000-00-00T00:00:00Z/9999-12-31T24:00:00Z.
member.param: The interval.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.WriteAvailability(CesiumLanguageWriter.JulianDate,CesiumLanguageWriter.JulianDate)
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a availability, which is the set of time intervals over which data for an object is available. The property can be a single string specifying a single interval, or an array of strings representing intervals. A later Cesium packet can update this availability if it changes or is found to be incorrect. For example, an SGP4 propagator may initially report availability for all time, but then later the propagator throws an exception and the availability can be adjusted to end at that time. If this optional property is not present, the object is assumed to be available for all time. Availability is scoped to a particular CZML stream, so two different streams can list different availability for a single object. Within a single stream, the last availability stated for an object is the one in effect and any availabilities in previous packets are ignored. If an object is not available at a time, the client will not draw that object. If not specified, the default value is 0000-00-00T00:00:00Z/9999-12-31T24:00:00Z.
member.param: The earliest date of the interval.
The latest date of the interval.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.WriteAvailability(System.Collections.Generic.IList{CesiumLanguageWriter.TimeInterval})
member.summary: Writes the value expressed as a availability, which is the set of time intervals over which data for an object is available. The property can be a single string specifying a single interval, or an array of strings representing intervals. A later Cesium packet can update this availability if it changes or is found to be incorrect. For example, an SGP4 propagator may initially report availability for all time, but then later the propagator throws an exception and the availability can be adjusted to end at that time. If this optional property is not present, the object is assumed to be available for all time. Availability is scoped to a particular CZML stream, so two different streams can list different availability for a single object. Within a single stream, the last availability stated for an object is the one in effect and any availabilities in previous packets are ignored. If an object is not available at a time, the client will not draw that object. If not specified, the default value is 0000-00-00T00:00:00Z/9999-12-31T24:00:00Z.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.PacketCesiumWriter.PositionWriter
member.summary: Gets the writer for the position property. The returned instance must be opened by calling the method before it can be used for writing. The position property defines the position of the object in the world. The position has no direct visual representation, but it is used to locate billboards, labels, and other graphical items attached to the object.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.WallCesiumWriter
member.summary: Writes a Wall to a . A Wall is a two dimensional wall defined as a line strip and optional maximum and minimum heights, which conforms to the curvature of the globe and can be placed along the surface or at altitude.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.GregorianDate
member.summary: Represents a calendar date in the Gregorian calendar. A does not include a as does. However, without explicitly specifying a for the date, the is assumed to be represented in . is also capable of representing leap seconds, which are represented as the second measured from 60 to 61. In this case, the is assumed to be the represented in which can represent leap seconds exactly.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.GregorianDate.Parser
member.summary:
This class was taken from the Mono class, and substantially altered to fit the needs of Gregorian Date. Gregorian Date assumes UTC, so all time-zone handling was ripped out. The "f" parsing was also changed to allow more precision than the 7 digits that mandates.
Note: any comment from here on is taken from the Mono source, so any references to bug numbers refer to their bugs.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.GregorianDate.Parse(System.String)
member.summary:
Converts the specified string representation of a date and time to its equivalent.
Note: is always assumed to be in UTC. You cannot parse strings containing time zone information. However, this will handle three common ISO8601 formats: the extended format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.sZ (with seconds to machine precision), it's "day of year" equivalent YYYY-DDDThh:mm:ss.sZ, and the basic format YYYYMMDDThhmmss.sZ.
member.returns: A equivalent to the date and time contained in s.
member.param: A string containing a date and time to convert.
member.exception: is null.
does not contain a valid string representation of a date and time.

However, this will handle three common ISO8601 formats: the extended format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.sZ (with seconds to machine precision), it's "day of year" equivalent YYYY-DDDThh:mm:ss.sZ, and the basic format YYYYMMDDThhmmss.sZ.
member.returns: A equivalent to the date and time contained in as specified by .
member.param: A string containing a date and time to convert.
An that supplies culture-specific format information about .
member.exception: is null.
does not contain a valid string representation of a date and time.

Converts the specified string representation of a date and time to its equivalent.
Note: is always assumed to be in UTC. You cannot parse strings containing time zone information. However, this will handle three common ISO8601 formats: the extended format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.sZ (with seconds to machine precision), it's "day of year" equivalent YYYY-DDDThh:mm:ss.sZ, and the basic format YYYYMMDDThhmmss.sZ.
member.returns: true if the parameter was converted successfully; otherwise, false.
member.param: A string containing a date and time to convert.

On input, an array with one element. On return, the array is populated with On return, the value equivalent to the date and time contained in , if the conversion succeeded, or if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the parameter is null, or does not contain a valid string representation of a date and time. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.JulianDate
member.summary: An astronomical Julian Date, which is the number of days since noon on January 1, -4712 (4713 BC). For increased precision, this class stores the whole number part of the date as an and the seconds into the day as a .
member.remarks: This type assumes that days always have (86400.0) seconds. When using a with the (UTC) time standard, a day with a leap second actually has 86401.0 seconds. The end result is that cannot represent the moment of a leap second with the UTC time standard. It CAN represent the moment of a leap second in (TAI), however. Also, subtracting two UTC dates that are on opposite sides of a leap second will correctly take the leap second into account.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.JulianDate.SecondsDifference(CesiumLanguageWriter.JulianDate)
member.summary: Computes the number of seconds that have elapsed from this Julian date to the Julian date.
member.param: The other Julian date, which is the end of the interval.
member.returns: The number of seconds that have elapsed from this Julian date to the other Julian date.
member.remarks: This method subtracts the Julian date on which it is called from the Julian date and returns the number of seconds between them. The computation is done in the time standard of this Julian date, or the closest standard that is safe for arithmetic if this Julian date's time standard is not safe. For best performance, this Julian date and the Julian date should have the same time standard and it should be safe for arithmetic.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.LeapSecond
member.summary: Describes a single leap second.
member.remarks: The International Earth Rotation Service (IERS) periodically introduces an intercalary adjustment to the Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) time scale in order to keep it in close agreement with the Universal Time (UT1) time scale. This adjustment amounts to a one second discontinuity, a leap second, in the UTC time scale that, in addition to the UT1 time scales, also affects transformations to other continuous time scales. Since the inception of leap seconds, all adjustments have been performed either at the end of 30 June or 31 December UTC though a leap second could, by rule, be applied at the end of any month.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.NearFarScalar
member.summary: A numeric value which will be linearly interpolated between two values based on an object's distance from the camera, in eye coordinates. The computed value will interpolate between the near value and the far value while the camera distance falls between the near distance and the far distance, and will be clamped to the near or far value while the distance is less than the near distance or greater than the far distance, respectively.

member.name: T:CesiumLanguageWriter.Reference
member.summary:
Represents a link to another property. References can be used to specify that two properties on different objects are in fact, the same property. This also has the added benefit of cutting down on CZML file size.
The formatted reference string contains the identifier of the target object followed by a hashtag (#) and one or more property names, each separated by a period (.). Any hash symbols or periods that exist in the reference identifier or property must be properly escaped with a backslash (\\) in order for the reference to be valid.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.Reference.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instance from an escaped reference string.
member.param: The reference string.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.Reference.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instance from an identifier and property.
member.param: The identifier of the object which contains the referenced property.
The property on the referenced object.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.Reference.#ctor(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Creates a new instance from an identifier and a list of properties.
member.param: The identifier of the object which contains the referenced property.
A list of property names with each property being a sub-property of the previous one.

member.summary: Gets the identifier of the object which contains the referenced property.

member.name: P:CesiumLanguageWriter.Reference.PropertyNames
member.summary: Gets the list of properties to be indexed on the referenced object.

member.summary: Gets the escaped CZML value of the reference.

member.summary: Gets the escaped CZML value of the reference.
member.returns: The escaped CZML value of the reference.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.StringFormatting.ToNonExponentialNotation(System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo,System.String)
member.summary: Reformats a string representation of a decimal floating point number, which may or may not be expressed in exponential notation, to eliminate the use of exponential notation. The formatted number is assumed not to contain any characters other than significant numbers, an optional negative sign in front of the number, an optional negative sign in front of the exponent, and an optional decimal separator specified by .
member.param: The format used to format the number. This is used to determine the decimal separator.
The formatted decimal floating point number.
member.returns: An equivalent number without the use of exponential notation.

member.name: M:CesiumLanguageWriter.YearMonthDay.GetAdjustedJulianDayNumber(CesiumLanguageWriter.JulianDate)
member.summary:
The constructor taking an integer Julian day number assumes that the desired should represent the Gregorian day corresponding to the beginning of the provided Julian day number. If the is more than one half day later than that, the calculation will be wrong.
So, if is more than 12 hours past the start of the Julian day, we instead use the Julian date number of tomorrow.
member.param: The date.
member.returns: The Julian day number that will produce the correct Gregorian day number.
